Actually, there's a very real reason why an empty fuel tank can explode. The remaining fuel vapour in a fully drained tank can end up at the perfect fuel:air ratio for detonation from the slightest spark. It's something that's a well known risk in the aerospace industry, and bulk fuel handling industries. The risk can be negated by an inerting system, filling the empty tank space with nitrogen.

With a properly designed and functioning inerting system, the tank is protected from vapour explosion, although any liquid fuel remaining could still explode if vaporised in a crash.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inerting_system

Nearly 20 years after TWA800, most non-combat aircraft still do not have an inerting system, and the FAA and industry are still debating the finer points of such systems. So, in the real world, it's more unusual to have an inerting system, than to have one, at least on planes. I'm uncertain if they are commonly used on today's real space missions Ã¢â‚¬â€ the weight and complexity penalties may be enough to discourage their use other than in cases where tank structural integrity requires pressurisation, or some other factor raises the risk above normal levels.

I'm uncertain of the current status of retrofitting A320s and 747s with such a system (they were the major cases flagged as having a higher risk factor).
